titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Papers of Eleanore Collins WAG.089
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Cara Brick

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from collins.xml

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-03-29T21:07-0400

did.abstract: Eleanore Collins had a passionate concern for labor education, women's rights, and white-collar organizing. Born in New York City, she graduated from Mount St. Vincent College and earned a Master's in industrial labor relations from Pace University. As a clerk with the American Telephone and Telegraph Co., she joined the Communications Workers of America, Local 1150 and by the early 1950s she became a steward. In the Union, she was active in organizing, upgrading clerical titles, boosting the status and pay for a female workers, and was elected to the Local's Executive Board. She remained active in telecommunications labor activities as a union board member, convention delegate, education director and finally president of the CWA, Local 1153, 1981-1984. She died in 1994. The collection includes correspondence, election materials, minutes, arbitration awards, clippings and reports reflecting both Collins' duties as a CWA Local officer and her personal political and community interests. NOTE: This collection is stored offsite, and advance notice is required for use.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Eleanore Collins donated one linear foot of her papers to the Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives in 1993. After her death in 1994, several additional boxes of material were donated by Mr. and Mrs. James Kennedy (Eleanore Collins's niece and her husband).

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open for research without restrictions. NOTE: This collection is stored offsite, and advance notice is required for use.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Eleanore Collins was born in the Bronx and raised in Elmsford, NY. She graduated from Mount St. Vincent College and later earned a Master's degree in industrial labor relations from Pace University. After working briefly for Reader's Digest and then as a social worker, she took a job as a clerk for the American Telephone and Telegraph Co. in Manhattan on the eve of World War II. In the early 1950s she joined the Communications Workers of America, Local 1150. In 1954 her clerical job was transferred to White Plains, NY. There she became a steward and was active in organizing and upgrading clerical titles. Thanks in large part to her efforts the new title of Engineering Associate, representing a substantial boost in status and pay for a female-dominated classification, was created within ATT.

She was elected to the Local's Executive Board and soon became known for her passionate concern with labor education, women's rights, and white-collar organizing. On two occasions, during a bitterly contested Local election in 1958-1959 and during the equally rancorous telephone strike of 1971, she came into conflict with members of her own and other CWA locals. Both disputes resulted in disciplinary proceedings; in each case, penalties against her were later set aside.

In 1975 she joined with a group of White Plains members who broke away to form a new CWA local, Local 1153. She went on to serve that Local as a Board member, convention delegate, education director and finally president, 1981-1984. She died in St. Louis, MO in June 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection, arranged in one series alphabetically by subject or organization name, includes correspondence, election materials, minutes, arbitration awards, clippings and reports reflecting both Collins' duties as a CWA Local officer and her personal political and community interests. Ranging from the political to the personal, these papers offer an alternative insight into union activities; an insight which is not offered in the official documentation of the Communications Workers of America.

As Collins' career with ATT progressed, her union activities with CWA Local 1150, and later Local 1153, document important work-related issues as well as broader issues of social policy. In her role as steward, Collins served as a counselor and mediator in cases of gender and racial discrimination, as well as sexual harassment. Within this collection, the cases of co-workers for whom Collins served as a steward highlight these issues. In addition, the papers record in detail shifts in the nature of the female work-force in the telephone industry that experienced a post-War "boom" built on technological advances and structural changes associated with World War II.

A significant amount of material found in this collection deals with the impact of ATT's divestiture during the mid-1980s. Documents concerning divestiture represent the efforts and positions of the CWA at the international as well as the local level. Several files offer statistical analysis on the impact of divestiture in terms of job loss and other issues of concern to the union.

A major aspect of Collins' work was her involvement with labor education. Teaching at local community colleges as well as in union-sponsored seminars, Collins created an extensive record of teaching expertise. Course descriptions, syllabi, lecture notes, stewards' training materials and lesson plans are included in this collection.

In addition to her educational activities, Collins was an active participant in many of the Local's elections. Information concerning Collins' campaigns as well as those of her opponents is well represented in the collection. Types of election election materials included are: handbills, flyers, biographies of the candidates, opposing literature, petitions, vote tallies and special election editions of newsletters. The bulk of this material dates from the years 1978-1988.

Controversy over disputed election results in CWA Local 1150's 1958-1959 election occasioned a disciplinary hearing against Eleanore Collins in 1960. Included in the documentation of the debate is the trial transcript. Background material detailing the charges brought against Collins and the disputed electoral results constitute one folder. The 1971 national strike by CWA against ATT led to further controversy and disciplinary hearings for Collins. In 1971, Collins supported a move by fellow co-workers to return to work at a time when the validity of the picket lines was in question. Other Local members accused Collins of defying union directives, and once again charges were brought against her. During the ensuing trial, the debate over local versus national authority with regard to the picket lines intensified. Collins' handwritten notes during the trial as well as the other materials used for her defense highlight the controversy. The charges against Collins were later dismissed. In an undated file marked "Writings" are typescript essays written by Collins on subjects such as women's employment in the White Plains unit of ATT, job losses in White Plains, and the telephone strike of 1971 in the New York area.

In the later years of her career, Collins' concern with union activities and efforts to aid in worker security inclined toward securing pensions and health benefits for employees and retirees. This concern extended to all those in need of health care, with an emphasis on senior citizens. Her interest in these areas is reflected in her involvement with the Bronx Community Board 12's Health and Hospital Committee and the Westchester Health Action Committee. Another significant committee on which Collins served was the White House Conference on Balanced National Growth and Economic Development in 1978.

p.emph: NOTE: This collection is stored offsite, and advance notice is required for use.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files are grouped into 1 series

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

list.item: CWA Newsand newsletters of CWA Locals 1150 and 1153;
a two-part oral history interview with Eleanore Collins conducted in 1991.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Some photographs accompanied the Eleanore Collins papers and have been transferred to the Wagner Labor Archives Non-Print Collection. There are also numerous examples of photographic images within the collection itself in the form of press clippings and election materials.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2630
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: peter.filardo@nyu.edu

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number;
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
